result.markdown:
# Workplace interaction Import some plotting libraries and set some defaults: ::: {#cell-2 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import sys import numpy as np import pandas as pd from IPython.display import display, Markdown import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns sns.set() sns.set_context(context='paper', font_scale=0.8, rc=None) # sns.set_context(context='notebook', font_scale=1, rc=None) sns.set_style("ticks", {"axes.spines.top": False, "axes.spines.right": False, "legend.edgecolor": 'white'}) import random random_seed = 5 sys.path.append('..') from global_params import load_params ``` ::: ::: {#cell-3 .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} %%html ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: > **Tip:** > Producing figures in svg format (scalable vector graphics) makes for sharp plots on webpages. However, if you make plots with thousands of observations you should set this to `'png'` instead: ::: {#cell-5 .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} %config InlineBackend.figure_formats = ['retina'] ``` ::: > **Tip:** > Some values apply globally to your analysis. E.g., sample sizes, cutoffs, names, rates, etc. Keeping those in a a yml file like `interaction_params.yml` and loading them in each notebook avoids the risk of manually adding/updating them in each notebook where they are used. You can use the `load_globals` function imported above from `global_params.py` to produce an object holding all the global values: ::: {#cell-7 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} params = load_params('../global_params.yml') params ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` {'sample_size': 24} ``` ::: ::: ::: {#cell-8 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} params.sample_size ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ``` 24 ``` ::: ::: ## Sampling ::: {#cell-10 .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} subjects = pd.read_csv('../data/data_table.csv') assert subjects.index.size == params.sample_size subjects ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: > **Tip:** > By adding a label and caption to a cell displaying a table, you can refer to that table elsewhere and insert it in a manuscript. ::: {#tbl-subjects .cell tbl-cap='People included in the analysis.' execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} # with pd.option_context('display.max_rows', None,): # prints *all* rows # display(subjects.style.hide()) # .style.hide() hides the index) subjects.style.hide() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: > **Tip:** > By generaing markdown for descriptions that will eventually end up in the manuscript, you can imbed python values. It also ensures that the manuscript exactly reflects the notebook. ::: {#cell-doc-sampling .cell execution_count=8} ::: {#doc-sampling .cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=8} The 24 subjects from workplaces in Denmark were interviewed .... blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah ::: ::: ## Interviews In interviewed 24 workplace individuals were interviewed by .... blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, ::: {#cell-18 .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} # generate some random sample data scores = pd.DataFrame({ 'name': subjects.name, 'informality': np.random.normal(loc=10, scale=1, size=params.sample_size) }) data = pd.merge(subjects, scores, on='name') data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ::: {#cell-fig-danishinteraction .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.figure(figsize=(4,3)) sns.scatterplot(x='age', y='informality', data=data, hue='position', palette='viridis') plt.ylabel('How informal you can be') plt.xlabel('Age') plt.legend(title='Seniority', loc='lower right') plt.ylim(bottom=0) ; ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Figure legends are defined alongside the figure in the notebook. The figure size in the notebook is determines its size when embedded in a document 4x3 inches.](example_files/figure-html/fig-danishinteraction-output-1.png){#fig-danishinteraction width=355 height=277} ::: ::: or plotted differently: ::: {#cell-fig-danishinteractionfacets .cell .column-page execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} #plt.figure(figsize=(4,3)) g = sns.FacetGrid(data=data, col="nationality",hue="position", palette='viridis', aspect=0.9) g.map(sns.scatterplot, 'age', 'informality') #sns.scatterplot(x='age', y='informality', data=data, hue='position', palette='viridis') plt.ylabel('How informal you can be') plt.xlabel('Age') plt.legend(title='Seniority', loc='lower right') ; ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Figure legends are defined alongside the figure in the notebook. The figure size in the notebook is determines its size when embedded in a document 4x3 inches.](example_files/figure-html/fig-danishinteractionfacets-output-1.png){#fig-danishinteractionfacets width=1552 height=286} ::: ::: Seems Danish people act very informally unaffected by age and seniority. ::: {#cell-23 .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} informality_age_cor = data.informality.corr(data.age) informality_age_cor ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ``` -0.044141763546043156 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#cell-24 .cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} mean_informality = data.groupby(['position', 'nationality']).informality.mean().to_frame().reset_index() mean_informality = mean_informality.sort_values('informality')#.style.hide() # hide index ``` ::: To show the `mean_informality` table, in a way that allow you to cite and embed it elsewhere, you need to provide a label, and preferably a caption, for it, as shown below. For this use, you also need to use the display function: ::: {#tbl-mean-informality .cell tbl-cap='Mean interaction scores by position and nationality.' execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} display(mean_informality) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
position nationality informality
0 PhDstudent CH 8.678369

5 Postdoc NL 10.006290
3 Postdoc DK 10.068812

8 Professor GB 11.017384
6 Postdoc US 11.531517
9 Professor UK 12.053566
``` ::: ::: > **Tip:** > To render a nice table without the index column, you can do this to the `display` function instead: > `Markdown(df.to_markdown(index=False))` > The table above shows the mean informality scores by ::: {#cell-fig-meaninformality .cell execution_count=15} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Figure legends are defined alongside the figure in the notebook. The figure size in the notebook is determines its size when embedded in a document 4x3 inches.](example_files/figure-html/fig-meaninformality-output-1.png){#fig-meaninformality width=431 height=277} ::: ::: ::: {#cell-doc-formality-correlation .cell execution_count=16} ::: {#doc-formality-correlation .cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=16} The correlation between informality and age was -0.044. ::: ::: ::: {#cell-fig-danish-interaction-regressions .cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.lmplot(x='age', y='informality', data=data, hue='position', palette='viridis', height=3, aspect=4/3) plt.ylabel('How informal you can be') plt.xlabel('Age') ; ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![Figure legends are defined alongside the figure in the notebook. The figure size in the notebook is determines its size when embedded in a document 4x3 inches.](example_files/figure-html/fig-danish-interaction-regressions-output-1.png){#fig-danish-interaction-regressions width=464 height=286} ::: :::
